questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is not a risk factor for chronic kidney disease?

options.d: Large for gestational age at birth

questions.explanation:
Small for gestational age (SGA) at birth is a risk factor for chronic kidney disease (CKD), not LGA. Important risk factors for CKD or chronic renal failure are: • SGA • Childhood obesity 702 
Sold by @itachibot • Hypertension • Diabetes mellitus • Autoimmune disease • Family history of kidney disease • Previous episode of acute kidney injury • Structural abnormalities of the urinary tract • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

questions.question: Question 2: What is the most common cause of chronic kidney disease?
questions.explanation: Diabetic nephropathy is the most common cause of chronic kidney disease (CKD). The leading causes of CKD in decreasing order of frequency are as follows: • Diabetic nephropathy • Glomerulonephritis • Hypertension-associated CKD • ADPKD (Adult or autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease)

questions.question: Question 3: Patients with which of the following conditions are unlikely to develop chronic renal failure?
questions.explanation:
Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is least likely to cause chronic renal failure. It 
is a rapidly progressive condition and a cause of acute renal failure.

questions.question:
Question 5: In patients with chronic kidney disease, at which stage do the complications of kidney failure 
start appearing?
questions.explanation:
The features of kidney failure become prominent as the GFR progressively declines to stages 3 
and 4. The following complications occur as a result of loss of kidney function: • Volume overload • Hyperkalemia • Metabolic acidosis • Hyperphosphatemia • Mineral and bone disorders • Hypertension 704 
Sold by @itachibot • Anemia • Dyslipidemia

questions.question:
Question 6: A 66-year-old woman is being evaluated for new-onset uremic encephalopathy. What is her 
GFR likely to be?
questions.explanation:
Clinical features of uremia start to appear in patients with GFR < 15 mL/min/1.73 m2 or 
end-stage renal disease (ESRD). By this stage, renal clearance is severely impaired and the 
accumulation of uremic toxins leads to several complications including: • Uremic encephalopathy • Pruritus • Malnutrition • Anorexia, nausea, fatigue • Platelet dysfunction • Sexual dysfunction • Pericarditis, pleuritis • Peripheral neuropathy Stages of Chronic Kidney Dis

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is incorrect about uremic syndrome?

options.a: It occurs due to accumulation of toxins
options.b: There is loss of kidney function and hormone regulation
options.d: Can be eliminated by removing urea through intensive dialysis

questions.explanation:
Uremic syndrome cannot be eliminated by removing urea alone. It is a complex condition 
occurring due to the accumulation of multiple toxins. The pathophysiology of uremic syndrome involves the following: • Accumulation of toxins (uremia) - urea, creatinine, other products of protein metabolism like 
urates, hippurates, polyamines, indoles. • Loss of kidney function leading to fluid and electrolyte imbalance and hormone dysregulation. • Progressive systemic inflammation with vascular and nutritional impairment. Clinical features secondary to loss of kidney function tend to develop in parallel with declining 
GFR. However the features of uremia and, hence, uremic syndrome, usually occur only in stage 5 
or ESRD.

questions.question:
Question 9: A middle-aged woman with chronic kidney disease presents to the OPD with exercise 
intolerance, fatigue, and shortness of breath. On examination, she is found to have severe 
pallor. Which of the following is least likely to be a cause for these findings?
questions.explanation: Sickle cell anemia is not a feature of chronic kidney disease (CKD). Common causes of anemia in CKD include: • Erythropoietin deficiency • Diminished red blood cell survival • Bleeding diathesis • Iron deficiency • Vitamin B12 and folate deficiency • Hyperparathyroidism (due to bone marrow fibrosis) • Hemoglobinopathy

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is not seen in patients with chronic renal failure?
questions.explanation:
Hyperthyroidism is not a feature of chronic renal failure. Option A: Peripheral neuropathy can occur secondary to uremia. Options C and D: In chronic renal failure, calcitriol (vitamin D3) production is decreased, leading 
to metabolic bone disease, which in turn leads to low serum calcium levels, secondary 
hyperparathyroidism, and osteomalacia.

questions.question: Question 11: What is the most common neurological disorder seen in patients with CKD?
questions.explanation:
The most common neurological disorder seen in patients with CKD is peripheral neuropathy. The various neuromuscular manifestations of CKD include: • Memory and concentration impairment • Dialysis dementia - due to aluminum intoxication 707 
Sold by @itachibot • Restless leg syndrome • Peripheral neuropathy • Hiccups • Cramps • Uremic encephalopathy • Confusion and lethargy • Tremors • Myoclonus • Asterixis • Seizures • Coma

questions.question:
Question 12: 697 
Sold by @itachibot A 27-year-old woman goes to her family doctor as she is unable to fall asleep at night. She 
complains of tingling and crawling sensations over her legs at night. She also feels a strong 
urge to move her legs, which relieves the symptoms for a while. Which of the following is 
incorrect about this condition?

options.c: Most common cause is chronic kidney disease
options.d: Most common movement disorder in pregnancy

questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of restless legs syndrome (RLS) or Willis-Ekbom disease. 
Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is not the most common cause of this condition. RLS is a neurological sleep disorder that can be primary or secondary. The primary form is more 
common. It shows autosomal dominant inheritance in most cases, but can be idiopathic. 
Secondary RLS is associated with the following: • Iron deficiency • Pregnancy - most common movement disorder • Peripheral neuropathy • Diabetes mellitus • CKD • Parkinson's disease • Multiple sclerosis It is characterized by an uncontrollable, restless urge to move the legs. It tends to worsen during 
periods of inactivity and at evening or night. It is accompanied by crawling, tingling or burning 
sensations. These symptoms show partial or complete improvement with movement. This cycle 
may continue for a while and result in insomnia. Primary RLS is managed by improving sleep hygiene and dopamine agonists (pramipexole or 
ropinirole) if symptoms persist. Iron supplements can also be given. In secondary RLS, the 
underlying cause must be treated.

questions.question: Question 13: What is the most likely cause of convulsions in a patient with CKD?
questions.explanation:
708 
Sold by @itachibot The most likely cause of convulsions in a patient with CKD is water intoxication. Volume overload 
in these patients as well as damage to the blood-brain barrier by uremic toxins causes cerebral 
edema and seizures.

questions.question: Question 14: What is most common cause of mortality in patients with chronic kidney disease?
questions.explanation:
Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in patients at every stage of 
CKD.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following would be elevated in patients with chronic kidney disease?
questions.explanation: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is associated with elevated levels of fibrinogen. CKD is a pro-inflammatory state characterized by altered levels of acute-phase reactants (APR) • Elevated levels of positive APR like CRP and fibrinogen (associated with high ESR). • Reduced levels of negative APR like albumin and fetuin.

questions.question: Question 16: What is the predominant electrolyte abnormality seen in patients with advanced CKD?
questions.explanation:
High anion gap metabolic acidosis is the predominant electrolyte abnormality in a patient with 
advanced CKD. In advanced CKD, impaired renal functioning causes decreased urinary excretion 
of acids. These retained organic acids result in a high anion gap. In early CKD, potassium retention is associated with bicarbonate loss. This gives rise to 
hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap in early CKD. The following electrolyte abnormalities are seen in CKD: • Hyperkalemia • Hypocalcemia • Hyperphosphatemia • Hyperuricemia • Hypermagnesemia Hypokalemia is uncommon in CKD and usually reflects markedly reduced dietary potassium 
intake, especially in association with excessive diuretic therapy or concurrent GI losses.

questions.question: Question 17: Which among the following is the most life-threatening manifestation of CKD?
questions.explanation:
Of the given options, hyperkalemia is the most life-threatening complication of chronic kidney 
disease (CKD) as it can result in cardiac arrhythmias and sudden death. 709 
Sold by @itachibot CKD is staged based on declining glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and albuminuria. The various 
clinical manifestations occur due to loss of kidney function and accumulation of various uremic 
toxins (urea, creatinine, and other products of protein metabolism). Complications of declining kidney function include: • Volume overload • Hyperkalemia • Metabolic acidosis • Hyperphosphatemia • Mineral and bone disorders • Hypertension • Anemia • Dyslipidemia

questions.question: Question 18: Patients with CKD have increased levels of all of the following except:
questions.explanation:
Serum estrogen levels are low in CKD patients. This leads to menstrual abnormalities and 
infertility. Option A: Plasma levels of insulin are elevated in CKD patients due to impaired clearance by the 
affected kidneys. Hence, insulin dose must be reduced in these patients. Option B: Elevated parathyroid hormone levels in CKD are secondary to derangements in the 
homeostasis of calcium, phosphate, and vitamin D. Option D: FGF-23 (fibroblast growth factor) is part of a family of phosphatonins that promotes 
renal phosphate excretion. The levels of this hormone increase early in the course of CKD.

questions.question:
Question 19: A patient presents to the emergency with chest pain that is radiating to his shoulder, 
shortness of breath, and diaphoresis. He is a known case of chronic kidney disease. Which of 
the following investigations is best for diagnosis?

options.b: Troponin levels on admission and 1 hour later
options.c: Troponin and CK-MB levels at admission

questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of acute myocardial infarction (MI) in a patient with chronic 
kidney disease (CKD). A serial rise in cardiac troponin levels over 3-6 hours following 
presentation is needed to make a diagnosis. An interval of 1-hour is not considered sufficient. Minor chronic elevations in serum troponins are commonly observed in patients with CKD even 
in the absence of cardiovascular disease. Hence, a single elevated troponin value in such patients 
cannot be used to diagnose MI. CK-MB is far less sensitive and specific than troponins. Hence, it is not preferred.

questions.question:
Question 20: Which of the following is the most sensitive test to detect early diabetic nephropathy in a 
patient?
questions.explanation:
710 
Sold by @itachibot Microalbuminuria is the most sensitive and earliest finding of diabetic nephropathy. It refers to 
urine albumin of 30–300 mg/24-hour urine. It is seen in the stage of incipient diabetic kidney 
disease. However, microalbuminuria is a very variable finding and is not required to diagnose 
nephropathy. Non-albuminuric diabetic nephropathy may occur in some patients and regression 
of albuminuria may be seen in type 1 diabetics. Diabetic nephropathy can be diagnosed if the following are satisfied: • Reduced GFR (< 60 mL/min/1.73 m2) with or without persistent albuminuria (> 30 mg/day 
or urine PCR > 30 mg/g) • Long duration of diabetes or established diabetic retinopathy • Other etiologies are ruled out

questions.question:
Question 21: A patient with chronic kidney disease is found to have normal-sized kidneys on 
ultrasonography. Which of the following diagnoses is least likely?
questions.explanation:
Hypertensive nephropathy is unlikely in this patient as it usually presents with shrunken kidneys. Longstanding CKD due to most causes results in bilaterally small kidneys. Causes of CKD with 
normal size kidneys are: • Diabetic nephropathy (kidney size may be increased at the onset) • Amyloidosis • HIV nephropathy

questions.question:
Question 22: A 65-year-old hypertensive patient has recently been diagnosed with stage 3 chronic kidney 
disease. According to the ESC 2018 guidelines, what target blood pressure would you choose 
for this patient?
questions.explanation:
711 
Sold by @itachibot According to the ESC 2018 guidelines, the target blood pressure in hypertensive patients with 
CKD is < 140/ 80 mm Hg regardless of age.

questions.question:
Question 23: A 50-year-old man who has been on dialysis for 2 years presents with bone pain and bowing 
of legs. Further evaluation reveals hyperparathyroidism and hyperphosphatemia. What is the 
initial treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of secondary hyperparathyroidism (HPT) and 
hyperphosphatemia in a patient with CKD. Sevelamer is the best initial treatment for this 
patient. It is a phosphate binder that reduces the absorption of phosphate from the 
gastrointestinal tract. Other phosphate binders that can be used include: • Calcium containing • Calcium acetate • Calcium carbonate • Non-calcium containing • Sevelamer • Lanthanum Calcitriol and cinacalcet are used to decrease PTH levels in secondary hyperparathyroidism. 
However, they also cause increased serum phosphate levels. Hence, they should not be given as 
initial treatment in patients with hyperphosphatemia. Bisphosphonates like pamidronate are used in the treatment of primary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.question:
Question 24: Which of the following is the most appropriate definitive treatment for anemia in patients 
with chronic kidney disease?
questions.explanation:
Anemia in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) is primarily due to decreased 
erythropoietin production. Hence, human recombinant erythropoietin (EPO) such as darbepoetin 
is the most appropriate treatment and is considered the mainstay. However, an optimal response to treatment with EPO occurs only when iron stores are adequate. 
Hence, iron supplements (oral or IV) must be given first to ensure the effectiveness of EPO 
therapy. Other treatment options for anemia in CKD are: • Vitamin B12 and folate supplementation • Blood transfusion - in severe anemia and failure to EPO therapy

questions.question: Question 25: Which of the following should not be used in a patient with CKD?
questions.explanation:
Diclofenac should not be used in a patient with CKD as it is nephrotoxic. 712 
Sold by @itachibot Renal blood flow is regulated by prostaglandin E2. Aspirin, diclofenac and other NSAIDs inhibit 
cyclooxygenase. This decreases prostaglandin E2 concentration, thereby causing a reduction in 
blood flow and GFR. Nephrotoxic drugs include the following: • NSAIDs • Antifungals (amphotericin B) • Antibiotics • Aminoglycosides • Vancomycin • Cephalosporins • Sulfonamides • Streptomycin • Antivirals • Acyclovir • Foscarnet • Chemotherapy drugs • Methotrexate • Platins • Immunosuppressants (cyclosporine)

questions.question:
Question 26: A 50-year-old man with type 2 diabetes has developed stage 4 CKD secondary to diabetic 
nephropathy. He currently takes insulin for his diabetes. What changes need to be made to 
his regimen?
questions.explanation:
In CKD patients with diabetes, the dose of insulin must be reduced. In CKD patients, the plasma levels of insulin are elevated due to diminished renal degradation of 
insulin by the impaired kidney. This impaired renal clearance of insulin can lead to hypoglycemia. 
Hence, the dose of insulin must be reduced to prevent this. 713 
Sold by @itachibot Acute Kidney Injury
